_package_info.description: Social standing backgrounds for the British Regency period (1811-1820) and broader Georgian era, covering all social classes across England, Scotland, Wales, and Ireland
_package_info.author: Storymaster

background.name: Duke/Duchess
background.description: Highest rank of nobility below royalty, holding vast estates and wielding enormous political influence. Commands respect from all levels of society and often sits in the House of Lords.

background.name: Marquess/Marchioness
background.description: High-ranking nobility, typically governing border territories or important regions. Possesses substantial wealth and political power, with multiple estates and titles.

background.name: Earl/Countess
background.description: Ancient title of nobility with significant landholdings and social influence. Often hereditary lords of historic counties with seats in Parliament and extensive patronage networks.

background.name: Viscount/Viscountess
background.description: Noble rank below Earl, often holding important administrative or military positions. Maintains country estates and London residences, moving in the highest social circles.

background.name: Baron/Baroness
background.description: Lowest rank of hereditary peerage, but still commanding considerable respect and resources. Often regional landowners with influence over local politics and society.

background.name: Baronet
background.description: Hereditary knighthood ranking above knights but below barons. Typically landed gentry with country estates, entitled to be addressed as 'Sir' or 'Lady' with social precedence.

background.name: Knight
background.description: Granted knighthood for service to Crown or country, entitled to 'Sir' or 'Dame'. May be military heroes, distinguished professionals, or those who purchased the honor.

background.name: Country Squire
background.description: Rural landowner and magistrate, the backbone of country society. Owns substantial estates, employs many locals, and serves as justice of the peace with considerable local authority.

background.name: Landed Gentleman
background.description: Property owner living off rental income without need for trade or profession. Educated, refined, and socially connected, often serving in local government or as church patron.

background.name: Landed Lady
background.description: Woman of property and independent means, whether inherited or through marriage settlements. Commands respect in society and may manage estates or charitable enterprises independently.

background.name: Military Officer (Army)
background.description: Commissioned officer in His Majesty's Army, holding rank through purchase or merit. Social standing varies by regiment and rank, but generally accepted in polite society.

background.name: Naval Officer
background.description: Officer in the Royal Navy, elevated in social standing due to naval victories against Napoleon. Prize money from captures can provide substantial wealth and advancement.

background.name: Clergyman (Church of England)
background.description: Anglican priest or rector, often younger sons of gentry. May hold comfortable livings with good income, especially if appointed by wealthy patrons or family connections.

background.name: Barrister
background.description: Legal advocate with right to argue in higher courts. Often well-educated gentleman who may combine law with politics, requiring significant education and social connections.

background.name: Physician
background.description: Medical doctor with university education, ranking above surgeons and apothecaries. Serves wealthy clientele and may achieve significant social standing through successful practice.

background.name: Wealthy Merchant
background.description: Successful trader or business owner who has accumulated substantial wealth. May purchase estates and seek to establish family in genteel society, though viewed with some suspicion by old families.

background.name: London Banker
background.description: Financier or partner in banking house, often extremely wealthy from government loans and international trade. Growing influence in politics and society despite commercial origins.

background.name: Mill Owner
background.description: Industrial entrepreneur profiting from textile manufacturing and new machinery. Represents new money and changing economy, often seeking social acceptance through wealth.

background.name: Ship Owner
background.description: Maritime entrepreneur owning merchant vessels engaged in trade. Wealth depends on successful voyages and may fluctuate dramatically with market conditions and naval warfare.

background.name: West Indies Plantation Owner
background.description: Owner of sugar, tobacco, or coffee plantations in Caribbean colonies. Often absentee landlords living in Britain on plantation profits, wielding considerable economic and political influence.

background.name: Governess
background.description: Educated woman employed to teach children of wealthy families. Occupies ambiguous social position - too genteel for servants' quarters but not family equal, often from reduced circumstances.

background.name: Companion
background.description: Respectable woman employed to provide company and assistance to wealthy lady. Usually of genteel birth but reduced means, maintaining social graces while in dependent position.

background.name: Estate Manager
background.description: Professional responsible for overseeing large country estates. Requires education and trustworthiness, often earning good income and respect from employers and local community.

background.name: Secretary/Clerk
background.description: Educated assistant to gentleman, nobleman, or professional. Handles correspondence, accounts, and administrative duties. May advance through merit and patron's favor.

background.name: Solicitor
background.description: Legal professional handling property transactions, wills, and local legal matters. Respectable position serving middle and upper classes, often becoming pillar of local community.

background.name: Shopkeeper
background.description: Owner of retail establishment serving local community. Social standing varies greatly by location and success, from barely respectable to wealthy and influential in market towns.

background.name: Master Craftsman
background.description: Skilled artisan owning workshop and employing apprentices. Represents respectable working class with potential for modest prosperity through skill and industry.

background.name: Tenant Farmer
background.description: Rents land from estate owner, ranging from prosperous yeoman to struggling subsistence farmer. Success depends on land quality, crop prices, and relationship with landlord.

background.name: Village Schoolmaster
background.description: Educated person teaching local children, often appointed by church or local benefactor. Modest but respectable position requiring literacy and moral character.

background.name: Innkeeper
background.description: Owner or manager of coaching inn or tavern. Important figure in local community, hosting travelers and serving as center for news and gossip. Income varies by location.

background.name: Butler
background.description: Head male servant in great household, responsible for wine cellar, plate, and supervising footmen. Position of considerable responsibility and respect within service hierarchy.

background.name: Housekeeper
background.description: Senior female servant managing household operations, supervising maids and maintaining domestic order. Trusted position with significant authority over daily household functioning.

background.name: Lady's Maid
background.description: Personal servant to lady of rank, responsible for dress, appearance, and private needs. Privileged position requiring discretion, skill, and often traveling with employer.

background.name: Valet
background.description: Personal manservant to gentleman, handling clothes, grooming, and private affairs. Position of trust and intimacy, often accompanying master on travels and social occasions.

background.name: Cook
background.description: Professional responsible for kitchen operations in wealthy household. Skilled position commanding respect and decent wages, especially in households known for fine dining.

background.name: Footman
background.description: Liveried male servant performing various duties from serving at table to accompanying carriages. Often young and presentable, with opportunities for advancement in household hierarchy.

background.name: Housemaid
background.description: Female domestic servant responsible for cleaning and maintaining household. Entry-level position with long hours but steady employment and potential for advancement to senior roles.

background.name: Groom
background.description: Servant responsible for horses and stable operations. Important position in era dependent on horse transport, requiring skill with animals and equipment maintenance.

background.name: Coachman
background.description: Professional driver of horse-drawn vehicles, from simple gigs to elaborate coaches. Skilled position requiring knowledge of routes, horse handling, and vehicle maintenance.

background.name: Scottish Laird
background.description: Scottish landowner with hereditary estate, may hold clan leadership or traditional authority. Social position varies greatly by wealth and political connections to London.

background.name: Highland Chieftain
background.description: Traditional leader of Scottish Highland clan, may retain ceremonial authority despite political changes. Position complicated by government restrictions following Jacobite uprisings.

background.name: Welsh Squire
background.description: Welsh country gentleman with local estates, often involved in mining, agriculture, or traditional crafts. May speak Welsh and maintain connections to local cultural traditions.

background.name: Irish Landlord
background.description: Estate owner in Ireland, may be Anglo-Irish Protestant or Catholic depending on family history. Often absentee landlord managing property from England through agents.

background.name: Irish Tenant
background.description: Renter of Irish agricultural land, typically Catholic and potentially engaged in secret societies or political movements. Economic situation often precarious and politically complex.

background.name: London Tradesman
background.description: Urban craftsman or small business owner serving city population. May achieve comfortable middle-class lifestyle through skill and business acumen in growing metropolitan economy.

background.name: Factory Worker
background.description: Industrial laborer in new manufacturing centers, representing changing economy and social conditions. Working and living conditions often harsh but wages may exceed agricultural labor.

background.name: Dock Worker
background.description: Laborer in major ports loading and unloading ships in Britain's maritime trade. Dangerous work but essential to empire's commerce, with strong community bonds and mutual aid societies.

background.name: Coal Miner
background.description: Underground worker extracting coal that powers Britain's industrial revolution. Extremely dangerous occupation with strong community solidarity and emerging political consciousness.

background.name: Agricultural Laborer
background.description: Rural worker employed seasonally or permanently on farms and estates. Lives at subsistence level but may have traditional rights and community support systems.

background.name: Pauper
background.description: Destitute person dependent on parish relief or workhouse accommodation. Represents growing social problem of urban poverty and displacement from traditional rural society.
